   Troponin-T:38//0.08, ALT / AST:46/26, Alk Phos / T Bili:67/0.2,
   Differential-Neuts:76.6 %, Lymph:15.7 %, Mono:6.0 %, Eos:1.1 %, Lactic
   Acid:1.2 mmol/L, Albumin:2.2 g/dL, LDH:238 IU/L, Ca++:8.1 mg/dL,
   Mg++:1.9 mg/dL, PO4:4.5 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Per report, patient was demonstrating increased
   work of breathing in the ED with resp rates in the 30s.  No ABG done
   prior to intubation.  Patient does have a history of COPD and CHF with
   last ECHO showing EF of 35-40%.  On arrival to the ICU, patient was
   demonstrated large negative pressures with low PIPs around 12.  Initial
   ABG was actually venous and was 7.16/56/48.  Repeat just after
   increased tidal volumes, ABG was 7.22/43/302 on FiO2 100%.  Likely has
   increased dead space in the setting of hypovolemia and hypoperfusion as
   well.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation as patient has component of respiratory acidosis in
   addition to non-AG metabolic acidosis
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.
   - Will check Urine AG
   - Nutrition consult for TPN
   - Avoid NS for resuscitation given hyperchloremia and hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   - Will cycle CE
   - Continue dilt gtt, will transition to home metoprolol as tolerated
   - IVF for dehydration
   - Continue to follow
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Will give D51/2NS now given dehydration and free water deficit
   - PM lytes
   - Urine lytes now
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12 and folate within
   normal limits.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Will send iron studies
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   - Continue coumadin 2.5 mg daily
   - Continue to trend INR
   - LUE US to rule out DVT at PICC site
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient appears dry on exam.  Likely
   pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or ATN as above.
   - Urine lytes
   - IVF resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renally dose all meds
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl
   - Will consult surgery for further recommendations regarding medical
   mgmt and abx course
   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, need to confirm placement, PIV
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2107-4-21**] 04:30 PM
   PICC Line - [**2107-4-21**] 05:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He is currently intubated for respiratory failure and has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, hypernatremia, and acute renal failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory acidosis and non-AG metabolic acidosis may worsen if not properly managed.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease if not treated promptly.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to central pontine myelinolysis if not corrected.
4. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to cardiac complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not treated promptly, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis may lead to pulmonary embolism if not properly managed.
7. Pancreatic mass: The patient's pancreatic mass may worsen if not properly managed, leading to pancreatic complications.
8. FEN (Febrile Non-Hemolytic Endocarditis): The patient's FEN may worsen if not properly managed, leading to endocarditis.
9. VAP (Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia): The patient's VAP may worsen if not properly managed, leading to pneumonia.
10. DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): The patient's DVT may worsen if not properly managed, leading to pulmonary embolism.

The patient's medical team should closely monitor his condition and adjust his treatment plan as necessary to prevent these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient was overbreathing
   the ventilator overnight when less sedated to increase pH and
   simultaneously driving down CO2.  Minute ventilation 12-17L/min.
   Patient has a history of COPD and likely chronically has a high CO2.
   Will not try to achieve his baseline CO2 currently as there is still an
   ongoing metabolic acidosis.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation around 12-13 L/min
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count.
   - Cont. cipro & flagyl
   - CT abdomen to examine for interval changes, worsening appendicitis
   vs. duodenal-pancreatic communication given low HCO3
   - f/u blood, urine, & sputum cultures
   - trend fever curve & WBC count.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   Patient has ruled out for an MI again.  Dilt drip stable at 10 mg/hr
   overnight with heart rates in the low 100s and SBP in the low 100s.
   Unable to transition to PO meds at this time as patient is NPO due to
   ruptured appendix.
   - Continue dilt gtt, titrate down as tolerated and transition to home
   metoprolol when able to take POs
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.
   - Switch to NaHCO3 for fluid resuscitation given hyperchloremia and
   hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Patient received 0.5 L D51/2NS then 1.5L D5W overnight.
   - transition to D5W + 3amps NaHCO3 for IVF
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient appears dry on exam.  Likely
   pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or ATN as above.  FENa
   1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - IVF resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renally dose all meds
   - nephrology consult
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, nutrition consult for
   TPN recs
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, need to confirm placement, PIV, will place A-line
   today
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, need to talk with HCP regarding patient
   overall status once further info from CT available.
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   .

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation and is currently intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has a complex medical history, including chronic kidney disease, anemia, and a pancreatic mass.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he requires continued mechanical ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation. The patient's history of COPD and chronic respiratory acidosis may contribute to his respiratory failure.
2. Fever: The patient's fever may be related to the ruptured appendix, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or an occult infectious process. The patient's white blood cell count is normal, which makes it difficult to determine the cause of the fever.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be related to atrial fibrillation, sinus tachycardia, or myocardial infarction. The patient's cardiac enzymes are normal, and a cardiac catheterization was negative for coronary artery disease.
4. Non-Acid-Base Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's acidosis may be related to saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, or increased amino acids in total parenteral nutrition (TPN). The patient's urine electrolytes show an anion gap, which suggests that the acidosis is not primarily related to a metabolic disorder.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is likely related to inadequate fluid replacement and may be contributing to his acidosis. The patient's calculated free water deficit is 2.8 liters.
6. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely related to hypovolemia, and his chronic kidney disease may be contributing to his anemia.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to chronic kidney disease, and his guaiac-positive stools may indicate bleeding.
8. Right Subclavian Vein Thrombosis: The patient's thrombosis may be related to his underlying medical conditions, and his subtherapeutic international normalized ratio (INR) may be contributing to his bleeding risk.
9. Ruptured Appendix: The patient's ruptured appendix is likely related to his underlying medical conditions, and his fever may be related to the infection.
10. Pancreatic Mass: The patient's pancreatic mass is likely stable, but it may be contributing to his anemia and hyperglycemia.

Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Manage the patient's fever with antibiotics and antipyretics.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
4. Continue to manage the patient's acidosis with sodium bicarbonate and adjust his fluid replacement regimen as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
6. Continue to manage the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's subclavian vein thrombosis and adjust his anticoagulation regimen as necessary.
8. Continue to manage the patient's ruptured appendix with antibiotics and antipyretics.
9. Monitor the patient's pancreatic mass and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
10. Consult with a nephrologist and a cardiologist to further manage the patient's complex medical conditions.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient was overbreathing
   the ventilator overnight when less sedated to increase pH and
   simultaneously driving down CO2.  Minute ventilation 12-17L/min.
   Patient has a history of COPD and likely chronically has a high CO2.
   Will not try to achieve his baseline CO2 currently as there is still an
   ongoing metabolic acidosis.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation around 12-13 L/min
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count.
   - Cont. cipro & flagyl
   - CT abdomen to examine for interval changes, worsening appendicitis
   vs. duodenal-pancreatic communication given low HCO3
   - f/u blood, urine, & sputum cultures
   - trend fever curve & WBC count.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   Patient has ruled out for an MI again.  Dilt drip stable at 10 mg/hr
   overnight with heart rates in the low 100s and SBP in the low 100s.
   Unable to transition to PO meds at this time as patient is NPO due to
   ruptured appendix.
   - Continue dilt gtt, titrate down as tolerated and transition to home
   metoprolol when able to take POs
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.
   - Switch to NaHCO3 for fluid resuscitation given hyperchloremia and
   hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Patient received 0.5 L D51/2NS then 1.5L D5W overnight.
   - transition to D5W + 3amps NaHCO3 for IVF
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient appears dry on exam.  Likely
   pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or ATN as above.  FENa
   1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - IVF resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renally dose all meds
   - nephrology consult
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, nutrition consult for
   TPN recs
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, need to confirm placement, PIV, will place A-line
   today
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, need to talk with HCP regarding patient
   overall status once further info from CT available.
   .

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has a complex medical history and is currently experiencing multiple complications, including:

* Respiratory failure: likely due to a combination of IVF, atrial fibrillation with respiratory acidosis, and profound metabolic acidosis
* Fever: may represent worsening of ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or an occult infectious process
* Tachycardia: likely due to atrial fibrillation, but may also be related to other factors such as sinus tachycardia with APBs/MAT or MAT
* Non-AG metabolic acidosis: differential includes saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA
* Hypernatremia: likely due to inadequate free water replacement
* Acute on chronic renal failure: likely pre-renal, but may also have a component of RTA or ATN
* Anemia: likely due to chronic kidney disease and acute phase reactant
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: likely due to DVT, but may also be related to other factors such as compression or trauma
* Ruptured appendicitis: medically managed, but may require surgical intervention if symptoms worsen
* Pancreatic mass: stable on repeat imaging

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: may lead to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis
* Fever: may lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and death
* Tachycardia: may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac failure
* Non-AG metabolic acidosis: may lead to organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, and death
* Hypernatremia: may lead to central nervous system dysfunction, seizures, and death
* Acute on chronic renal failure: may lead to uremic complications, electrolyte imbalances, and death
* Anemia: may lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, organ dysfunction, and death
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: may lead to pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, and death
* Ruptured appendicitis: may lead to peritonitis, abscess formation, and death if left untreated
* Pancreatic mass: may lead to pancreatic insufficiency, diabetes, and death if left untreated

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation, and chronic heart failure. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and is now intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: intubated for respiratory failure, likely due to a combination of IV fluid overload, atrial fibrillation with RVR, and profound metabolic acidosis.
* Hemodynamic status: atrial fibrillation with RVR, likely due to septic state, and mixed venous oxygen saturation is high, suggesting distributive shock.
* Renal status: acute on chronic renal failure, likely pre-renal, with a fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) of 1.26%, suggesting a component of tubular injury.
* Electrolyte status: hypernatremia has resolved, but the patient is still at risk for developing metabolic acidosis due to the ongoing IV fluid administration.
* Infection status: the patient has a history of ruptured appendicitis and is currently being treated with Vanc/Zosyn, but the source of the infection is unclear. There is also concern for possible fungal infection, and the patient has been started on fluconazole.
* Cardiovascular status: the patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR and is receiving pressor support with norepinephrine.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Worsening respiratory failure due to continued IV fluid overload and atrial fibrillation with RVR.
* Development of septic shock due to ongoing sepsis and distributive shock.
* Progression of acute on chronic renal failure to end-stage renal disease.
* Development of metabolic acidosis due to continued IV fluid administration and possible underlying tubular injury.
* Fungal sepsis or fungemia due to the patient's current antibiotic regimen and possible underlying fungal infection.
* Cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias, due to ongoing atrial fibrillation with RVR and possible underlying cardiac disease.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, atrial fibrillation, and chronic heart failure. He was admitted with hypernatremia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and respiratory failure, and is currently intubated.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His ABG values are improving, and a trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV) is planned to anticipate weaning off the ventilator.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which is likely due to a septic state. He has a mixed venous O2 saturation of 73%, suggesting distributive shock. His blood pressure is being supported with vasopressors, and a trial of phenylephrine is planned to eliminate positive chronotropy.
* Fever: The patient's fever may be due to worsening of the ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or an occult infectious process. He has been switched to Vanc/Zosyn and fluconazole for empiric coverage of fungal infections.
* Non-AG metabolic acidosis: The patient's acidosis has resolved, and his urine electrolytes with anion gap are being trended.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia has resolved, and he is being monitored for any signs of rehydration.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's renal function is improving, and he is being renally dosed with medications.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia appears to be partially dilutional, and his B12, folate, and iron levels are within normal limits.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a significant erythema and edema of his right upper extremity, and is being treated with heparin and coumadin.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Sepsis: The patient's septic state could worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen, leading to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response could lead to cardiac arrest.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure could worsen, leading to electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
* Infection: The patient's fever and positive blood cultures could indicate a serious infection, such as fungemia.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and guaiac-positive stools could indicate gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on this information, the patient requires continued close monitoring and management of his respiratory, hemodynamic, and metabolic status. He should also be treated for his septic state, and his antibiotic regimen should be adjusted based on the results of his microbiology studies.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient was overbreathing
   the ventilator overnight when less sedated to increase pH and
   simultaneously driving down CO2.  Minute ventilation 12-17L/min.
   Patient has a history of COPD and likely chronically has a high CO2.
   Will not try to achieve his baseline CO2 currently as there is still an
   ongoing metabolic acidosis.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation around 12-13 L/min
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count.
   - Cont. cipro & flagyl
   - CT abdomen to examine for interval changes, worsening appendicitis
   vs. duodenal-pancreatic communication given low HCO3
   - f/u blood, urine, & sputum cultures
   - trend fever curve & WBC count.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   Patient has ruled out for an MI again.  Dilt drip stable at 10 mg/hr
   overnight with heart rates in the low 100s and SBP in the low 100s.
   Unable to transition to PO meds at this time as patient is NPO due to
   ruptured appendix.
   - Continue dilt gtt, titrate down as tolerated and transition to home
   metoprolol when able to take POs
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.
   - Switch to NaHCO3 for fluid resuscitation given hyperchloremia and
   hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Patient received 0.5 L D51/2NS then 1.5L D5W overnight.
   - transition to D5W + 3amps NaHCO3 for IVF
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient appears dry on exam.  Likely
   pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or ATN as above.  FENa
   1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - IVF resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renally dose all meds
   - nephrology consult
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, nutrition consult for
   TPN recs
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, need to confirm placement, PIV, will place A-line
   today
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, need to talk with HCP regarding patient
   overall status once further info from CT available.
   .
   # Disposition: pending above

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure. He has a ruptured appendix, which is being medically managed with antibiotics, and has been on ciprofloxacin and flagyl since admission. He has also been experiencing tachycardia, fever, and non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. His laboratory results show acute kidney injury, anemia, and hypernatremia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including IVF, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and profound metabolic acidosis. The patient's history of COPD and chronic hypercapnia may also contribute to his respiratory failure.
2. Fever: The patient's fever may represent worsening of his ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or an occult infectious process.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be due to atrial fibrillation, sinus tachycardia, or myocardial infarction. The patient has been ruled out for myocardial infarction, but the cause of his tachycardia remains unclear.
4. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may be due to saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids in TPN, or renal tubular acidosis.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely due to pre-renal azotemia, although there may be a component of renal tubular acidosis or acute tubular necrosis.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is likely due to inadequate free water replacement and may be exacerbated by his chronic kidney disease.
7. Ruptured appendix: The patient's ruptured appendix is being medically managed with antibiotics, but there is a risk of worsening infection and complications such as peritonitis or abscess formation.
8. Pancreatic mass: The patient has a history of a pancreatic mass, which may be stable or progressing.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed to achieve a target minute ventilation of 12-13 L/min.
2. Continue to manage the patient's fever with antibiotics and consider repeating CT scans to evaluate for interval changes or worsening of his appendicitis.
3. Titrate the patient's sedation and pain management to minimize the risk of respiratory depression and tachycardia.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his fluid management accordingly to avoid further hypernatremia and hyperchloremia.
5. Consider nephrology consult to evaluate the patient's acute kidney injury and develop a plan for renal replacement therapy if necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusions if necessary.
7. Consider placing a central line to facilitate administration of medications and fluids.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's pancreatic mass and consider repeat imaging to evaluate for any changes.

ICU Care:

1. Nutrition: The patient is receiving TPN with lipids and will require ongoing nutritional support.
2. Glycemic control: The patient's blood glucose levels should be monitored regularly to ensure tight glycemic control.
3. Lines: The patient has a PICC line, arterial line, and PIV, which will require ongoing monitoring and maintenance.
4. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving prophylactic anticoagulation with heparin gtt and will require ongoing monitoring to ensure adequate anticoagulation.
5. Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk for stress ulceration and will require ongoing monitoring and prophylaxis with histamine-2 blockers.
6. VAP: The patient is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia and will require ongoing monitoring and prophylaxis with antibiotics and chest physiotherapy.

Summary:

The patient is a 66-inch tall individual with atrial fibrillation (AF) who was admitted to the ICU with sepsis, renal failure, and metabolic acidosis. They have a history of chronic kidney disease and have been treated with antibiotics, including Ciprofloxacin, Metronidazole, and Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 99.8°F, heart rate of 121 bpm, and blood pressure of 87/52 mmHg. They are receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, neutrophil count, and C-reactive protein (CRP), indicating an active infection. Their renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 4.1 mL/min/m2. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are normal, and their electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for hypernatremia (high sodium).

The patient's imaging studies, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis, did not show any evidence of peripancreatic fistula or drainable fluid collection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen if not properly managed, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Renal failure: The patient's impaired renal function may worsen if not managed properly, leading to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen if not managed properly, leading to cardiovascular instability, arrhythmias, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk for developing DVT due to their immobility and underlying medical conditions.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to respiratory acidosis, hypoxia, and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as pressure ulcers and infection.
7. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen if not properly managed, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and potentially life-threatening complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and sepsis. He has a history of ruptured appendix and is currently experiencing recurrent hypotension, pre-renal azotemia, and acidosis. The patient's condition is complicated by a possible catheter-related bloodstream infection and pneumonia. He is receiving mechanical ventilation and pressors to support his blood pressure. His laboratory results show elevated creatinine and lactate levels, as well as a low albumin level.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen if not properly treated, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to further cardiac complications, such as stroke or heart failure, if not properly managed.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's pre-renal azotemia and acidosis may progress to acute renal failure if not properly treated, leading to life-threatening complications.
4. Catheter-Related Bloodstream Infection: The patient's catheter-related bloodstream infection may lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and potentially life-threatening complications if not properly treated.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen if not properly treated, leading to respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's persistent hypotension and tachycardia may lead to cardiac arrest if not properly managed.
7. Multi-Organ Dysfunction Syndrome: The patient's sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction may lead to multi-organ dysfunction syndrome, which can be life-threatening.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to treat the patient's sepsis with broad-spectrum antibiotics and source control measures.
2. Manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with rate control medications and consider cardioversion if necessary.
3. Continue to treat the patient's acidosis and pre-renal azotemia with fluids and electrolyte replacement.
4. Monitor the patient's catheter-related bloodstream infection and consider removing the catheter if necessary.
5. Treat the patient's pneumonia with antibiotics and consider intubation if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider intubation if necessary.
7. Consider transferring the patient to a higher level of care if his condition deteriorates.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and is now intubated for respiratory
   failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). ABG much better now
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat high suggestive of distributive shock. [**Month (only) 11**] also have a
   component of cardiogenic shock, however, given pt
s HR has gone up, now
   persistently in 130s. + pressor requirement for BP support. Dilt gtt
   was d/c
d yesterday. [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim checked (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL.
   - Consider trial of phenylephrine instead of levophed to eliminate
   positive chronotropy
   - Consider adding oral BBker for rate control
   - Consider chemical cardioversion with amio
   - PE unlikely given pt has been on lovenox, now on heparin gtt.
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 24 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn yesterday given decompensation.
   - Add fluconazole for empiric coverage of fungal (stop TPN while
   getting treated for ?fungemia)
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - CT negative for any drainable abscesses.
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: resolved.
   - monitor
   - judicious use of normal saline
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated.  Likely pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or
   ATN as above.  FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - appreciate nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - appreciate [**Doctor First Name **] recs
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, hold TPN while
   +suspicion of fungemia.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, A-line, PIV. Likely needs a fem line given the
   number of IV medications pt is receiving.
   .
   # Code: Full
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), and congestive heart failure (CHF). He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) and is now intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 573 mL.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient has a heart rate of 118 beats per minute, with a blood pressure of 95/56 mmHg. He has a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 27.6% and a central venous pressure of 24 mmHg.
* Renal status: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 51 mg/dL. He is receiving fluids and has a urine output of 2,720 mL.
* Metabolic status: The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, which has resolved. He has a hypernatremia, which has also resolved.
* Infectious status: The patient has a fever, which may be due to a ruptured appendix, aspiration pneumonitis, or an occult infectious process. He is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam.
* Hematologic status: The patient has anemia, which may be due to chronic kidney disease, iron deficiency, or gastrointestinal bleeding. He has a platelet count of 372,000/μL and a white blood cell count of 9.8,000/μL.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
* Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is low, and he may require continued vasopressor support.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he may require continued fluid management and consideration of renal replacement therapy.
* Infection: The patient has a fever and is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, which may be necessary to manage potential infections.
* Bleeding: The patient has a platelet count of 372,000/μL, which may be low, and he may be at risk for bleeding.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's heart rate is elevated, and he may require continued monitoring and management of his cardiovascular status.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode.
* Monitor the patient's hemodynamic status closely and adjust vasopressor support as necessary.
* Manage the patient's renal status with continued fluid management and consideration of renal replacement therapy.
* Monitor the patient's infectious status closely and adjust antibiotic therapy as necessary.
* Monitor the patient's hematologic status closely and consider transfusions if necessary.
* Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely and adjust management as necessary.

It is also recommended that the patient's family be informed of his condition and the plan of care, and that they be involved in decision-making regarding his care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR, and is currently intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38°C, heart rate of 118 bpm, and blood pressure of 95/56 mmHg. His respiratory status is being managed with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of sepsis, with an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and C-reactive protein (CRP). His blood cultures are pending, and he has been started on broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient's renal function is compromised, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 27 mg/dL. He has been receiving IV fluids and has been started on a renal dose of medications.

The patient's anemia is likely due to a combination of factors, including chronic kidney disease (CKD), gastrointestinal bleeding, and inadequate nutrition. His hemoglobin level is 9.1 g/dL, and his hematocrit is 27.6%.

The patient has a history of right subclavian vein thrombosis (RSVT) and is currently receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin and coumadin. He has also been started on a bowel regimen to prevent constipation.

The patient's pancreatic mass is being followed as an outpatient, and he has been advised to follow up with his primary care physician.

The potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC and CRP levels suggest that he may be developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's compromised renal function and elevated BUN and creatinine levels suggest that he may be at risk for AKI.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is being managed with CPAP and PEEP, and he may require further respiratory support if his condition deteriorates.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR and hypotension suggest that he may be at risk for cardiovascular instability.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and elevated BUN and creatinine levels suggest that he may be at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Pancreatic mass progression: The patient's pancreatic mass is being followed as an outpatient, and he may require further evaluation and treatment if it progresses.

In summary, this patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions, including sepsis, AKI, respiratory failure, cardiovascular instability, gastrointestinal bleeding, and a pancreatic mass. He requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and optimize his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and chronic kidney disease (CKD). He was admitted with hypernatremia and AFib with RVR, and is currently intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient has several potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, with a trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV) in anticipation of weaning off the ventilator. The patient's mixed venous oxygen saturation is high, suggestive of distributive shock, and his heart rate has increased to the 130s, which may indicate a component of cardiogenic shock.
2. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's blood pressure is supported with norepinephrine, and his mixed venous oxygen saturation is high, suggesting a distributive shock. The patient's heart rate has increased to the 130s, which may indicate a component of cardiogenic shock.
3. Fever: The patient has a fever, which may be related to aspiration pneumonitis, occult infection, or worsening of the ruptured appendicitis. The patient's white blood cell count is normal, and he has been afebrile for 24 hours, which may indicate that he is not mounting a robust inflammatory response due to his age and chronic illness.
4. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient's acid-base status has improved, but he still has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, which may be related to saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, or increased amino acids in total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level has resolved, but he is still at risk for hypernatremia due to his underlying CKD and possible electrolyte imbalances.
6. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and he is at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI) due to his underlying CKD and possible prerenal, postrenal, or tubular factors.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to his underlying CKD, and he may require further evaluation and treatment.
8. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a significant thrombosis in his right subclavian vein, which may be related to his underlying CKD and possible venous stasis.
9. Ruptured appendicitis: The patient's ruptured appendicitis is medically managed, but he is at risk for further complications, such as abscess formation or sepsis.
10. Pancreatic mass: The patient's pancreatic mass is stable on repeat imaging, but he may require further evaluation and treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a 66-inch tall individual with a weight not specified, admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of atrial fibrillation (AFib) and respiratory failure. The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease, and is currently on vasopressors, amiodarone, and other medications. The patient has a central venous catheter (CVC) placed, and has undergone cardioversion attempts without success.

The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 36.2°C, heart rate 118 bpm, blood pressure 95/56 mmHg, respiratory rate 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 98%. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, consistent with sepsis. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with hypernatremia and hypocalcemia.

The patient's physical examination reveals marked swelling of both upper extremities, with right arm oozing transudative fluid. The patient is not following commands and winces to painful stimuli.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's laboratory results suggest sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not treated promptly and effectively.
2. Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and current use of vasopressors may increase the risk of DVT.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to acute kidney injury and further complications.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's AFib may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to further complications such as stroke and heart failure.
6. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's marked swelling of both upper extremities may lead to impaired skin integrity and increased risk of skin breakdown.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to further complications such as seizures and brain damage.
8. Hypocalcemia: The patient's hypocalcemia may worsen if not managed effectively, leading to further complications such as muscle cramps and cardiac arrhythmias.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-inch tall individual with a weight not specified, admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of atrial fibrillation (AF) with rapid ventricular response (RVR). The patient has a history of chronic renal failure and is currently experiencing sepsis without organ dysfunction.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 118 beats per minute (bpm) with a range of 107-155 bpm
* Blood pressure: 95/56 mmHg with a range of 70/48-110/66 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 13 breaths per minute (bpm) with a range of 13-29 bpm
* Oxygen saturation: 98%

The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows:

* Central venous pressure (CVP): 24 mmHg
* Total fluid intake: 8,245 mL with a total output of 2,720 mL
* Blood products transfused: 2,720 mL
* Urine output: 2,720 mL
* NG tube output: Not specified

The patient is receiving the following medications:

* Amiodarone: 0.5 mg/min
* Midazolam: 1.5 mg/hour
* Heparin: 650 units/hour
* Fentanyl: 50 mcg/hour
* Norepinephrine: 0.14 mcg/kg/min
* Levophed: Overnight, weaned off of vasopressin
* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn): 4:00 AM

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 9.8-11.0 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.1-10.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 372-395 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.7-2.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 17-20 mg/dL
* Sodium: 139-141 mg/dL
* Potassium: 3.5-4.5 mEq/L
* Chloride: 115-119 mEq/L
* Carbon dioxide: 16-20 mmHg
* Glucose: 104-156 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.2 g/dL
* LDH: 238 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.1-8.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2-2.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.5-4.5 mg/dL

The patient's diagnosis includes:

* Acidosis, metabolic
* Deep venous thrombosis (DVT), upper extremity
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* Hypernatremia (high sodium)
* Renal failure, chronic (chronic renal failure, CRF, chronic kidney disease)
* Atrial fibrillation (AF)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Impaired skin integrity

The patient's plan includes:

* ICU care
* Nutrition: Glycemic control
* Lines: PICC line, arterial line, and multi-lumen line
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of sepsis
* Development of organ dysfunction
* Progression of chronic renal failure
* Increase in blood pressure and heart rate
* Development of arrhythmias
* Respiratory failure
* Impaired skin integrity
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Pulmonary embolism
* Sepsis-induced acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Hypernatremia-induced neurological complications
* Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to glycemic control

It is essential to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and hemodynamic parameters closely to prevent and manage these potential complications.

   81 yo male with history of ruptured appendicitis now re-admitted with
   hypotension consistent with sepsis but have not been able to clearly
   identify new source.  He has had significant improvement with
   Amiodarone in regards to heart rate and although cardioversion failed
   he has had improved heart rate control and occasional sinus beats.
   1)Shock--Likely combined sepsis and cardiogenic contribution and will
   Rx as-->
   Sepsis--Continue with broad spectrum ABX and PRN fluid
   bolus-_Vanco/ZOsyn
definative source of recurrent infection not clearly
   Levophed to wean and Vasopressin to wean off
   A-Fib--Continue with amiodarone
   and->will attempt to provide wean of levophed as primary measure to
   evaluate improvement in hemodynamics.
   2)Respiratory Failure-Patient with good tolerance of decreased in PSV
   and having minimal secretions and actually opening eyes to voice.  Most
   challenging issue is persistent tachycardia, persistent hypotension.
   Secretions minimal
   -SBT this morning
   -Check ABG at 30 minutes
   -Will need to check anesthesia notes as to difficulty of airway.
   -metabolic issues (acidosis), possible pulmonary edema, poor mental
   status are all barriers that must be considered.
   3)Acute Renal Failure-he does have stable creatinine across time
   -Will provide HCO3- as needed for acidosis should HCO3- decrease below
   16
   -Appreciate renal input
   -Will renal dose all medications
   4)Atrial Fibrillation-
   _Failed cardioversion
   -Continue Amiodarone
   -Hope for SR conversion
   5)Thrombosis-DVT
   -Continue with Heparin
   -To Coumadin when stable
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male admitted to the ICU with sepsis, hypotension, and atrial fibrillation. He has a history of ruptured appendicitis and has been readmitted with recurrent infection. Despite broad-spectrum antibiotics and fluid boluses, the patient's hypotension persists. Cardioversion was attempted but failed. The patient is receiving Amiodarone for heart rate control and is being weaned off Levophed. He is also receiving Heparin for DVT prophylaxis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to continue to worsen if the source of infection is not identified and treated promptly. Sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, respiratory failure, and cardiovascular instability.
2. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's persistent hypotension and low cardiac output may indicate cardiogenic shock, which can be life-threatening. Cardiogenic shock can be caused by a variety of factors, including cardiac tamponade, myocardial infarction, and cardiomyopathy.
3. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, with persistent tachycardia and hypotension. He may be at risk for further deterioration, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and respiratory failure.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are stable, but he may be at risk for acute kidney injury (AKI) due to sepsis, hypotension, and nephrotoxic medications.
5. Thrombosis: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobility and underlying medical conditions.
6. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient's acid-base status is abnormal, with a pH of 7.35. He may be at risk for further acidosis due to sepsis, hypotension, and inadequate resuscitation.
7. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely to continue to worsen if not treated promptly. Atrial fibrillation can lead to cardiogenic shock, stroke, and heart failure.

Recommendations:

1. Identify and treat the source of sepsis promptly.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
3. Wean the patient off Levophed and Vasopressin to evaluate improvement in hemodynamics.
4. Continue Amiodarone for heart rate control and atrial fibrillation.
5. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust therapy as necessary.
6. Provide HCO3- as needed for acidosis.
7. Continue Heparin for DVT prophylaxis and transition to Coumadin when stable.
8. Consider consulting a nephrologist for further management of acute kidney injury.
9. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent further deterioration.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Was not extubated last night
   due to hemodynamic instability. Needs
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Try RSBI and SBT,
   if favorable, extubate later today
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (very sedated)
   and minute volume requirement required to compensate for metabolic
   acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Cardiology was consulted last night;
   recommended digoxin loading.
   - Continue chemical cardioversion with amio, digoxin (dose by level
   given ARF)
   - Wean levophed as tolerated by MAP > 65
   - f/u cardiology recs
   - consider repeating echo
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. There is a concern
   for fungal infection given pt
s prolonged abx course and frequent
   hospital stays.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn [**4-23**] given decompensation. (Day 3 today)
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied empiric fluconazole; will f/u glucan and galactomannin and
   re-assess once data available.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated.  Likely pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or
   ATN as above.  FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - F/u nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   - Transition to coumadin if extubated
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, TF/po intake post
   extubation
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from OSH
 will pull when hemodynamically stable),

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR. He was intubated for respiratory failure and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. His current condition is critical, with tachycardia, hypotension, and poor hemodynamics. He has been receiving various medications, including amiodarone, digoxin, and levophed, and has had several medical complications, including non-AG metabolic acidosis, hypernatremia, acute on chronic renal failure, and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Cardiogenic shock due to CHF and/or septic shock
	* Atrial fibrillation with RVR may lead to cardiac arrhythmias and decreased cardiac output
	* Digoxin loading may help to convert atrial fibrillation to sinus rhythm
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Respiratory failure due to IVF and/or pneumonia
	* Need for mechanical ventilation may lead to ventilator-associated complications, such as ventilator-induced lung injury and pneumonia
	* Weaning from mechanical ventilation may be challenging due to patient's poor hemodynamics and respiratory status
3. Renal Complications:
	* Acute on chronic renal failure may lead to worsening kidney function and electrolyte imbalances
	* Need for renal replacement therapy may be necessary if patient's kidney function continues to decline
4. Infection Complications:
	* Fever may represent worsening of ruptured appendicitis or aspiration pneumonitis
	* Need for broad-spectrum antibiotics and surveillance blood cultures to identify potential infections
5. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to anemia and/or coagulopathy
	* Need for blood transfusions and/or platelet transfusions to support patient's blood count
6. Neurological Complications:
	* Sedation and/or paralysis may lead to neurological complications, such as delirium and/or respiratory failure
	* Need for close neurological monitoring and adjustment of sedation and/or paralysis as necessary

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and/or treat these complications.

   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. There is a concern
   for fungal infection given pt
s prolonged abx course and frequent
   hospital stays.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn [**4-23**] given decompensation. (Day 3 today)
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied empiric fluconazole; will f/u glucan and galactomannin and
   re-assess once data available.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses to 150 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - F/u nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 14.5L positive).
   He was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   - Warfarin started yesterday for bridging.
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed; TF started yesterday [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, TF started yesterday
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt and warfarin,
   lansoprazole (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission), A-line, R fem CVC [**4-23**]
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart); will speak with HCP again today or tomorrow to give update.
   .
