   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS 12/5 well this
   morning, but NIF only -11.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **].
   -
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs last night per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. Discuss switching to PO amio and d/c
   digoxin
   - Wean levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue lasix (started yesterday [**4-26**]) with goal 1L negative today
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 6
   today)
   - Start fluconazole today for fungemia
   - Surveillance blood cultures - NGTD
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Has
   received Bicarb. Likely to improve with diuresis.
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Cr stable at 1.8
 2.0. Patient now
   adequately fluid resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely
   pre-renal.
   - monitor closely as lasix is being given
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 15L positive).  He
   was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT. INR therapeutic at 2.2.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**7-17**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also adding
   fluconazole today
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed; TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, TF with incr free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission), A-line, R fem CVC [**4-23**]
   (consider pulling PICC when possible given possible fungemia)
   .
   # Code: Full
   .

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with PS 15/5. He had previously tolerated PS 12/5 well, but did not tolerate PS 15/5 due to tachypnea and tachycardia.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to septic state. He has a mixed venous O2 saturation, suggesting distributive shock. His cardiac function is compromised, and he did not respond well to inotropic agents.
* Renal function: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL. He is being treated with lasix and is receiving fluid resuscitation.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 3,303 mL of fluid over the past 24 hours, with a net balance of -1,397 mL.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has hypernatremia, with a sodium level of 147 mEq/L. He also has a metabolic acidosis, with a pH of 7.44.
* Infection: The patient has a positive B-glucan test, indicating a fungal infection. He has also been diagnosed with MRSA, and is being treated with fluconazole.
* Other medical conditions: The patient has a history of anemia, and is being treated with iron supplements. He also has a history of pancreatitis, and is being followed by an oncologist.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he may require further treatment with inotropic agents.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, and he may require further treatment with dialysis.
* Infection: The patient has a positive B-glucan test, indicating a fungal infection. He may require further treatment with antifungal agents.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has hypernatremia, and may require further treatment with diuretics to correct this imbalance.
* Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, and may require further treatment with iron supplements.

The patient's current medications include:

* Fluconazole
* Warfarin
* Lasix
* Metoprolol
* Diltiazem

The patient's vital signs include:

* Oxygen saturation: 97%

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR. He was intubated for respiratory failure and has been on mechanical ventilation with a PSV of 15 cmH2O. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 101 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/55 mmHg. His respiratory status is stable, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 240 and a RSBI of 77.

Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he remains intubated due to his underlying respiratory disease and atrial fibrillation with RVR.
2. Hemodynamics: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to his septic state. He has also had a mixed venous O2 saturation of 95%, suggesting distributive shock. His blood pressure has been stable, but he has had episodes of hypotension.
3. Abdominal pain: The patient has been experiencing abdominal pain, which may be related to his ruptured appendix or other underlying conditions.
4. Fever: The patient has been febrile, with a temperature of 37.1°C, which may be related to his underlying infections or other conditions.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's serum sodium level has been elevated, which may be related to his underlying conditions or medications.
6. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease and has been experiencing acute kidney injury. His creatinine level has been stable, but he has been receiving fluids and diuretics to manage his volume status.
7. Anemia: The patient has a history of anemia, which may be related to his underlying conditions or medications.
8. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and has been receiving anticoagulation therapy.
9. Ruptured appendicitis: The patient has a history of ruptured appendicitis, which has been medically managed with antibiotics and fluids.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has been intubated and has a history of respiratory disease, which may increase his risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of septic shock and has been receiving antibiotics and fluids to manage his volume status.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and may be at risk for developing other cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal disease and may be at risk for developing gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Renal failure: The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease and may be at risk for developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease progression.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's hemodynamics with fluids, diuretics, and vasopressors as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's abdominal pain and fever and adjust his antibiotics and fluids as needed.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hypernatremia with fluids and diuretics as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust his transfusions as needed.
6. Continue to manage the patient's right subclavian vein thrombosis with anticoagulation therapy.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's ruptured appendicitis and adjust his antibiotics and fluids as needed.
8. Consider switching the patient to a different antibiotic regimen if his current antibiotics are not effective.
9. Consider adding a second antibiotic to the patient's regimen if his current antibiotics are not effective.
10. Consider switching the patient to a different anticoagulation regimen if his current regimen is not effective.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, atrial fibrillation, and chronic kidney disease. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR), and was intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and a tidal volume of 500 mL. He has a moderate amount of secretions and is at risk for aspiration pneumonia.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to a septic state. He has a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 95%, suggesting distributive shock. His blood pressure is 109/55 mmHg, and his heart rate is 101 beats per minute.
* Hemodynamic status: The patient's central venous pressure is not reported, but his mixed venous oxygen saturation suggests that he may have a component of cardiogenic shock.
* Renal status: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL. He is receiving lasix to promote diuresis and is being monitored closely for any signs of worsening renal function.
* Electrolyte status: The patient's sodium level is 144 mmol/L, and his potassium level is 3.6 mmol/L. He is receiving free water boluses to correct his hypernatremia.
* Infection status: The patient has a positive beta-glucan test, indicating a fungal infection. He is being treated with fluconazole, and surveillance blood cultures are being monitored.
* Other laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 7.3 x 10^9/L, and his platelet count is 333 x 10^9/L. His lactate level is 1.1 mmol/L, and his troponin level is 0.08 ng/mL.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation increase his risk of aspiration pneumonia, particularly given his moderate amount of secretions.
* Sepsis: The patient's septic state, as evidenced by his atrial fibrillation with RVR and mixed venous oxygen saturation, increases his risk of developing sepsis.
* Worsening renal function: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure and receipt of lasix increase his risk of worsening renal function, particularly if he becomes volume-depleted.
* Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is 3.6 mmol/L, which is slightly elevated. He is at risk for hyperkalemia, particularly if he develops acute kidney injury or receives medications that can cause potassium retention.
* Fungal sepsis: The patient's positive beta-glucan test and receipt of fluconazole indicate that he has a fungal infection. He is at risk for developing fungal sepsis, particularly if his infection is not adequately treated.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR and mixed venous oxygen saturation increase his risk of developing cardiovascular complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor the patient's respiratory status closely.
* Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR, including the use of beta-blockers and anticoagulation therapy.
* Monitor the patient's renal status closely and adjust his diuretic therapy as needed.
* Continue to treat the patient's fungal infection with fluconazole and monitor his response to therapy.
* Monitor the patient's electrolyte status closely, particularly his potassium level, and adjust his electrolyte replacement therapy as needed.
* Consider adding stress ulcer prophylaxis to the patient's medication regimen to reduce his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely, particularly his blood pressure and heart rate, and adjust his medication regimen as needed to prevent cardiovascular complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR. He was intubated for respiratory failure and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition has been unstable, with fluctuations in his vital signs, including tachycardia and tachypnea. He has also been experiencing abdominal pain, fever, and hypernatremia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and he continues to require mechanical ventilation. The possibility of respiratory failure persists, particularly if the patient's underlying condition worsens or if there are complications related to intubation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR may be a sign of underlying cardiac disease, and the risk of cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock, remains high.
3. Abdominal complications: The patient's abdominal pain and distension may be indicative of intra-abdominal pathology, such as bowel obstruction or perforation, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
4. Infectious complications: The patient's fever, positive B-glucan, and MRSA screen positivity suggest the possibility of an underlying infection, which could be severe and life-threatening.
5. Renal complications: The patient's acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) put him at risk for further renal deterioration and potential need for dialysis.
6. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's history of DVT and the presence of a PICC line and A-line increase his risk for VTE.
7. Pancreatic complications: The patient's pancreatic mass and the possibility of pancreaticitis or pancreatitis-related complications, such as sepsis, should be monitored closely.
8. Nutritional complications: The patient's malnutrition and electrolyte imbalance may lead to further complications, such as sepsis, if not properly managed.
9. Hematological complications: The patient's anemia and potential bleeding risk due to his anticoagulation therapy and history of gastrointestinal bleeding should be monitored closely.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
2. Closely monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider further cardiac evaluation, such as an echocardiogram, to assess his cardiac function.
3. Investigate the patient's abdominal pain and distension further, including a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis, to rule out intra-abdominal pathology.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and adjust his antipyretic therapy as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and consider further renal evaluation, such as a renal ultrasound, to assess his renal status.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's VTE risk and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's pancreatic mass and consider further evaluation, such as a pancreatic function test, to assess its impact on his overall health.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust his nutrition therapy as needed to prevent further malnutrition.
9. Monitor the patient's hematological status closely and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as needed to prevent bleeding complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's health progress in the ICU is as follows:

The patient's condition remains stable, with no significant changes in their vital signs or laboratory results. They continue to require mechanical ventilation and vasopressors to maintain blood pressure. The patient's respiratory rate and fatigue have increased, prompting a switch from pressure support to assist-control ventilation at night.

The patient's abdominal pain has resolved, and they are tolerating feeds well. Their stool cultures have been sent for analysis, and the right femoral central venous catheter was removed and sent for culture.

The patient's laboratory results show ongoing metabolic acidosis, chronic renal failure, and hypernatremia. Their liver function tests, lipase, and amylase are within normal limits.

The patient's medical conditions include sepsis without organ dysfunction, deep venous thrombosis in the upper extremity, atrial fibrillation, and respiratory failure. They also have impaired skin integrity and a history of chronic kidney disease.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing respiratory failure may lead to further deterioration in their lung function, requiring increased ventilatory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis without organ dysfunction may progress to sepsis with organ dysfunction, leading to multi-organ failure.
3. Deep venous thrombosis: The patient's DVT may extend to other areas, leading to pulmonary embolism or other complications.
4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to stroke or other cardiovascular complications if left untreated.
5. Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal failure may worsen, leading to acute kidney injury or end-stage renal disease.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to central pontine myelinolysis or other neurological complications if left untreated.
7. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity may lead to further complications, such as infection or pressure ulcers.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

   Assessment and PlanThis is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p
   resection, prostate ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD,
   SVT, CHF and ruptured appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with
   hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS 12/5 well this
   morning, but NIF only -11.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **].
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. d/c
d digoxin yesterday and amio
   converted from gtt to po yesterday.
   - Wean levophed as tolerated
   - minimize sedation as pt becomes hypotensive easily
   - d/c
d lasix yesterday around midnight due to hypotension; continues
   to make good urine although lasix was discontinued; Will not restart
   lasix for now
   .
   # Abdominal pain: difficult to assess as pt
s sensorium is not
   completely clear, however it
s worrisome given his history of medically
   managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling well (1-3 times a day),
   C.diff neg x 1, and has no residuals with TF.
   - Hold TF for now
   - Check KUB for ileus or obstruction
   - Consider CT abd/pelvis if KUB negative and exam becomes more
   worrisome
   - check LFTs, [**Doctor First Name **], lipase
   - Consider [**Doctor First Name **] consult
   - recheck C. diff
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 7
   today)
   - Started fluconazole yesterday for positive B-glucan
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   ..
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Cr stable at 1.8
 2.0. Patient now
   adequately fluid resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely
   pre-renal.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 15L positive).  He
   was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT. INR therapeutic at 2.1.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**8-16**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also started Fluc
   yesterday
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed; TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with incr free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; Will
   pull R fem CVC today as amio has now been converted from gtt to PO.
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart); will discuss possible need for trach/peg in the future
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care while intubated

   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from

   chest.

d digoxin yesterday and amio

   - d/c
d lasix yesterday around midnight due to hypotension; continues

   lasix for now
   .
   # Abdominal pain: difficult to assess as pt
s sensorium is not

s worrisome given his history of medically
   managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling well (1-3 times a day),

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and was intubated for respiratory failure. He has been receiving mechanical ventilation and has been weaned off levophed. His current vital signs include a temperature of 37.9°C, heart rate of 96 bpm, blood pressure of 94/45 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 7.4
* Hemoglobin: 10.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 309
* Creatinine: 1.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 25 mEq/L
* Sodium: 137 mg/dL
* Potassium: 4.0 mEq/L
* Chloride: 112 mEq/L
* Phosphate: 3.2 mg/dL
* Calcium: 7.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.5 g/dL
* Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 208 IU/L
* Troponin-T: 0.08 ng/mL
* Creatine kinase (CK): 38 IU/L
* CKMB: 0.08 ng/mL
* Alkaline phosphatase (ALP): 125 IU/L
* Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT): 22 IU/L
* Bilirubin: 0.2 mg/dL
* Amylase: 27 IU/L
* Lipase: 22 IU/L
* FENa: 1.26%
* TCO2: 22 mmHg
* pH: 7.43
* PaO2/FiO2: 275
* RSBI: 158
* PIP: 28 cmH2O
* Plateau: 20 cmH2O
* SpO2: 96%

The patient's medications include:

* Fentanyl: 20 mcg/hour
* Midazolam (Versed): 0.5 mg/hour
* Norepinephrine: 0.04 mcg/Kg/min
* Vancomycin: 1 g every 12 hours
* Fluconazole: 200 mg every 24 hours
* Piperacillin: 4 g every 6 hours
* Lasix: 40 mg every 12 hours (discontinued due to hypotension)
* Digoxin: 0.25 mg every 24 hours (discontinued)
* Amiodarone: 150 mg every 12 hours
* Metoprolol: 25 mg every 12 hours

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be due to a combination of factors, including his underlying lung disease, atrial fibrillation with RVR, and profound metabolic acidosis.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may be due to his underlying kidney disease and may be exacerbated by his current fluid status.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which may be due to his underlying kidney disease or acute kidney injury.
* Septic shock: The patient's mixed venous oxygen saturation is high, which may indicate distributive shock.
* Pulmonary embolism: The patient's erythema and edema of the right upper extremity may indicate a pulmonary embolism.
* Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain may be due to his underlying medical conditions, including his history of ruptured appendix and chronic kidney disease.
* Fever: The patient's fever may be due to a variety of factors, including his underlying medical conditions, his recent antibiotic therapy, and his current fluid status.

The patient's potential medical complications are being managed with a variety of medications and interventions, including:

* Mechanical ventilation
* Levophed weaning
* Fluid resuscitation
* Antibiotic therapy
* Anticoagulation therapy
* Stress ulcer prophylaxis
* VAP prophylaxis
* DVT prophylaxis
* Bowel regimen
* Prophylactic antibiotics

The patient's code status is full code.

   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may

d digoxin yesterday and amio

d lasix yesterday around midnight due to hypotension; continues

   # Abdominal pain: difficult to assess as pt
s sensorium is not

s worrisome given his history of medically

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), is currently intubated in the ICU due to respiratory failure. He has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and has been on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 96%. He is receiving continuous mechanical ventilation (CMV) with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's hemodynamic status is also stable, with a heart rate of 96 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 94/45 mmHg. He has a history of septic shock and has been treated with vasopressors and antibiotics.

The patient's abdominal pain has resolved, and he is stooling well with no residuals. His liver function tests (LFTs) and lipase levels are within normal limits.

The patient has a fever, which may be due to aspiration pneumonitis, occult infection, or other causes. He has been treated with antibiotics and has a positive B-glucan level, which suggests a fungal infection.

The patient has hypernatremia, which is being treated with free water boluses. His acute kidney injury is stable, and he is receiving renally dosed medications.

The patient has a right subclavian vein thrombosis, which is being treated with warfarin. He has a history of ruptured appendicitis, which has been medically managed with antibiotics.

The patient's pancreatic mass is being followed as an outpatient.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is still intubated and requires mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of respiratory failure if his ventilation settings are not adjusted properly.
2. Septic shock: The patient has a history of septic shock and has been treated with vasopressors and antibiotics. There is a risk of recurrent septic shock if his infection is not properly managed.
3. Abdominal complications: The patient has a history of ruptured appendicitis and has been treated with antibiotics. There is a risk of abdominal complications, such as abscesses or perforation, if his infection is not properly managed.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which can lead to neurological complications if not properly treated.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient has acute kidney injury, which can lead to chronic kidney disease if not properly managed.
6. Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a right subclavian vein thrombosis, which can lead to pulmonary embolism if not properly treated.
7. Fungal infection: The patient has a positive B-glucan level, which suggests a fungal infection. There is a risk of fungal sepsis if his infection is not properly managed.

Overall, the patient's health progress in the ICU is stable, but there are potential medical complications that can arise from his conditions.

   Assessment and PlanThis is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p
   resection, prostate ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD,
   SVT, CHF and ruptured appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with
   hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS better each
   day, although RSBI was 158 early this morning.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **]. (RSBI 90-100 and NIF -18 during rounds)
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   - OOB into chair today (PT consult)
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. On PO amio now with rate mostly in
   90s-110s.
   - On very low dose levophed at this time (0.02 mcg/kg/min); suspect
   will be able to wean it off completely once all sedation is lifted.
   - No lasix at this time as pt auto-diuresing post-ATN
   .
   # Abdominal pain: difficult to assess as pt
s sensorium is not
   completely clear, however it
s worrisome given his history of medically
   managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling well (1-3 times a day),
   C.diff neg x 1, and has no residuals with TF. KUB neg for ileus or
   obstruction. LFTs, amylase, lipase all WNL. Repeat C-diff pending.
   - Will hold off on further investigation for now; talk to patient once
   extubated for better history. The next step would be CT of abdomen and
   pelvis.
   - Continue TF as tolerating well with no residuals.
   .
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]; repeat pending
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 8
   today)
   - On day 3 of fluconazole which was started for positive B-glucan (Day
   3 today)
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   ..
   # Hypernatremia: better with D5W x 1L yesterday.
   - hold off on further D5W infusions; give PRN after checking PM lytes
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Resolving. Cr better this morning at
   1.6. UOP very good with likely post-ATN diuresis.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable after 2 u pRBCs on [**4-26**].   B12,  folate, & iron  within normal
   limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and
   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)
   off and on (with anticoagulation/INR 2.2)
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic 2.2 today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**9-16**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also started Fluc on
   [**4-27**] for + B-glucan
   - TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; R fem
   CVC pulled yesterday.
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care while intubated

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, atrial fibrillation with RVR, CHF, and ruptured appendix, who was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR. He was intubated for respiratory failure and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's condition has been improving, with his respiratory rate decreasing and his oxygen saturation increasing.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including IVF, atrial fibrillation with RVR, and profound metabolic acidosis. He is currently tolerating positive pressure ventilation (PSV) and will need to be weaned off the ventilator.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR is likely due to a septic state, and he may have a component of cardiogenic shock. He has been treated with amiodarone and metoprolol, and his cardiac function is being monitored closely.
3. Abdominal Complications: The patient has a history of ruptured appendix and is at risk for further complications. He has been experiencing abdominal pain, which is difficult to assess due to his altered sensorium. He has been stooling well and has no residuals with TF, but further investigation is needed to rule out ileus or obstruction.
4. Fever: The patient's fever may be due to worsening of his appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or another occult infectious process. He has been treated with antibiotics and antifungals, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his fever.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia has been improving with D5W infusions, but he will need to be closely monitored to prevent further electrolyte imbalances.
6. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's acute kidney injury is resolving, but he will need to be closely monitored for further changes in his renal function.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic kidney disease and may be exacerbated by his acute illness. He will need to be closely monitored for further changes in his hemoglobin levels.
8. Right Subclavian Vein Thrombosis: The patient has a significant thrombosis of his right subclavian vein, which is being treated with warfarin. He will need to be closely monitored for further changes in his clotting function.
9. Ruptured Appendix: The patient has a history of ruptured appendix and is at risk for further complications. He has been treated with antibiotics and antifungals, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his fever and abdominal pain.
10. Pancreatic Mass: The patient has a history of pancreatic mass, which is being followed as an outpatient.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and sepsis. He has a prolonged hospital course, including a recent ruptured appendix, and is currently experiencing respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, and sepsis with hypotension.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 94 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 115/60 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, indicating an ongoing inflammatory response. His blood cultures remain negative, and his fever is controlled.

The patient's medical history is significant for a recent ruptured appendix, and he has been receiving antibiotics, including Zosyn and Vanco, for sepsis. He is also receiving anticoagulation therapy with Coumadin for deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

The patient's physical examination reveals a thin patient with symmetric chest expansion and rhonchorous breath sounds. His abdominal examination is notable for soft, non-tender abdomen with bowel sounds present.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and use of antibiotics may increase his risk of developing VAP.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) extension: The patient's DVT may extend or develop new thrombi, which could lead to pulmonary embolism or other complications.
3. Sepsis progression: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction or failure.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, requiring further interventions such as tracheostomy or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
5. Atrial fibrillation progression: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen, leading to heart failure or other cardiac complications.
6. Muscle weakness: The patient's muscle weakness may worsen, making it difficult to wean him off mechanical ventilation.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's prolonged hospital course may lead to nutritional deficiencies, including malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan has been proposed:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute.
2. Wean the patient off sedation and consider using a fentanyl patch for pain management.
3. Continue antibiotics for sepsis and monitor for signs of infection.
4. Continue anticoagulation therapy for DVT.
5. Monitor the patient's laboratory results, including white blood cell count, platelet count, and LDH levels, to assess the effectiveness of treatment.
6. Consider performing a repeat NIF test to evaluate the patient's muscle strength and assess the need for further interventions.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve his outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS better each
   day, although RSBI was 158 early this morning.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **]. (RSBI 90-100 and NIF -18 during rounds)
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   - OOB into chair today (PT consult)
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. On PO amio now with rate mostly in
   90s-110s.
   - On very low dose levophed at this time (0.02 mcg/kg/min); suspect
   will be able to wean it off completely once all sedation is lifted.
   - No lasix at this time as pt auto-diuresing post-ATN
   .
   # Abdominal pain: difficult to assess as pt
s sensorium is not
   completely clear, however it
s worrisome given his history of medically
   managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling well (1-3 times a day),
   C.diff neg x 1, and has no residuals with TF. KUB neg for ileus or
   obstruction. LFTs, amylase, lipase all WNL. Repeat C-diff pending.
   - Will hold off on further investigation for now; talk to patient once
   extubated for better history. The next step would be CT of abdomen and
   pelvis.
   - Continue TF as tolerating well with no residuals.
   .
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]; repeat pending
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 8
   today)
   - On day 3 of fluconazole which was started for positive B-glucan (Day
   3 today)
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   ..
   # Hypernatremia: better with D5W x 1L yesterday.
   - hold off on further D5W infusions; give PRN after checking PM lytes
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Resolving. Cr better this morning at
   1.6. UOP very good with likely post-ATN diuresis.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable after 2 u pRBCs on [**4-26**].   B12,  folate, & iron  within normal
   limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and
   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)
   off and on (with anticoagulation/INR 2.2)
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic 2.2 today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**9-16**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also started Fluc on
   [**4-27**] for + B-glucan
   - TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; R fem
   CVC pulled yesterday.
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care while intubated

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a complex medical history, including lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, atrial fibrillation, and chronic heart failure. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR, and was intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is still intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a RSBI of 116. The plan is to continue PSV and wean off the ventilator when the RSBI is within normal limits.
* Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to septic state. He has received vasopressor support and is on low-dose levophed.
* Abdominal pain: The patient has a history of ruptured appendicitis and is currently experiencing abdominal pain, which is difficult to assess due to his altered mental status. The plan is to hold off on further investigation for now and discuss the next steps with the patient once he is extubated.
* Fever: The patient has a fever, which may be related to aspiration pneumonitis, occult infectious process, or worsening of his underlying condition. He has received antibiotics and antifungals, and further microbiological studies are pending.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia has improved with D5W infusions, and he will continue to receive free water boluses and monitor his sodium levels.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are improving, and he will continue to receive renally dosed medications.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is likely related to his chronic kidney disease. He will continue to receive blood transfusions as needed.
* Right subclavian vein thrombosis: The patient has a significant thrombosis in his right subclavian vein, and is on warfarin therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is still intubated and on mechanical ventilation, and there is a risk of respiratory failure if the ventilator is weaned too quickly or if the patient experiences a respiratory infection.
* Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis and is at risk of developing sepsis again, particularly if his underlying conditions are not well-controlled.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation and is at risk of developing cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or heart failure.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of ruptured appendicitis and is at risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation or abscesses.
* Renal complications: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure and is at risk of developing further renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease progression.
* Venous thromboembolism: The patient has a significant thrombosis in his right subclavian vein and is at risk of developing further venous thromboembolism.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient tolerated PSV this
   morning with NIF +28.
   - attempt extubation today
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   - OOB into chair today (PT consult)
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.  Levophed off.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. On PO amio now with rate mostly in
   90s-110s.
   - No lasix at this time as pt auto-diuresing post-ATN
   - pt. was on metoprolol as an outpatient for rate control, can consider
   restarting as BP improves
   .
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis with course to end on [**4-22**].  Fever may represent
   worsening of this process vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation
   vs. other occult infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not
   have an elevated WBC count and has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may
   not be able to mount a robust inflammatory response due to older age
   and general chronically ill state. CT negative for any drainable
   abscesses. B-glucan floridly positive (>500) which is not surprising
   given pt
s prolonged abx courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN.
   Yeast in urine and sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative x 2
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 9
   today). Plan for 10 day total course
   - On day 4 of fluconazole which was started for positive B-glucan (D1 =
   [**4-27**]).  Plan for 7 day course?
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Absent today.  Previously was difficult to assess as
   pt
s sensorium was not completely clear, however it was worrisome given
   his history of medically managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling
   well (1-3 times a day), C.diff neg x 2, and has no residuals with TF.
   KUB neg for ileus or obstruction. LFTs, amylase, lipase all WNL.
   - Will hold off on further investigation for now; talk to patient once
   extubated for better history. The next step would be CT of abdomen and
   pelvis.
   - Continue TF as tolerating well with no residuals.
   .
   # Hypernatremia: better with D5W.
   - hold off on further D5W infusions; give PRN after checking PM lytes
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Resolving. Cr better this morning at
   1.3. UOP very good with likely post-ATN diuresis.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable after 2 u pRBCs on [**4-26**].   B12,  folate, & iron  within normal
   limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and
   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)
   off and on (with anticoagulation/INR 2.2)
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic 2.0 today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - increase warfarin again to 2.5 mg as INR barely therapeutic
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Vanc/zosyn and fluconazole as above
   - TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with free water flushes held pending
   extubation.  Will try on clears later today if successfully extubated
   and has a good gag.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; R fem
   CVC pulled [**4-28**].
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care, if does well post
   extubation, potential c/o to floor tomorrow.
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix, admitted to the ICU with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR. He was intubated for respiratory failure and has been receiving antibiotics and antifungal therapy. The patient has been experiencing fever, abdominal pain, and anemia. He has a PICC line and an arterial line in place. The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory: intubated, on mechanical ventilation, with a respiratory rate of 33 breaths per minute and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 293.
* Cardiovascular: atrial fibrillation with RVR, with a heart rate of 98 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 96/48 mmHg.
* Neurological: alert and follows commands, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15.
* Abdominal: soft, non-tender, and distended, with bowel sounds present.
* Laboratory results: WBC count 7.4, Hct 29.3, Plt 269 K/uL, Cr 1.3 mg/dL, and glucose 117 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is high, and his PaO2/FiO2 ratio is low, indicating respiratory failure. He may require further respiratory support or extubation.
2. Atrial fibrillation with RVR: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely due to septic state, and he may require further cardiac monitoring and management.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic kidney disease and may require further management with blood transfusions or erythropoietin therapy.
4. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain is likely due to his history of ruptured appendix and may require further investigation with imaging studies.
5. Fever: The patient's fever may be due to an occult infectious process or aspiration pneumonitis, and he may require further antibiotic therapy or antifungal therapy.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is likely due to his history of medical management of a ruptured appendix and may require further management with D5W infusions and free water boluses.
7. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely due to his history of medical management of a ruptured appendix and may require further management with renally dosed medications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and monitor the patient's respiratory status.
2. Continue antibiotic and antifungal therapy for the patient's suspected septic state.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider further cardiac management.
4. Consider further investigation of the patient's abdominal pain with imaging studies.
5. Monitor the patient's fever and consider further antibiotic therapy or antifungal therapy.
6. Continue D5W infusions and free water boluses to manage the patient's hypernatremia.
7. Monitor the patient's acute kidney injury and consider further management with renally dosed medications.

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a prolonged hospital course due to recent ruptured appendix, prolonged respiratory failure, and sepsis. He has a history of lung and prostate cancer, COPD, DVT, and CHF. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 255. He has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which has shown improvement with Amiodarone and improved volume status. The patient has also had difficulty with ventilator weaning due to rapid and shallow breathing, which is concerning for significant muscle weakness.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Prolonged respiratory failure: The patient's prolonged respiratory failure may lead to further complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, lung damage, and respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may continue to progress, leading to organ dysfunction, septic shock, and death.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to further complications, such as stroke, heart failure, and arrhythmia.
4. DVT: The patient's DVT may lead to further complications, such as pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, and leg swelling.
5. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure may continue to progress, leading to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalance, acidosis, and end-stage renal disease.
6. Pancreatic mass: The patient's pancreatic mass may continue to cause symptoms, such as abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, and may lead to further complications, such as pancreatitis and pancreatic cancer.
7. Muscle weakness: The patient's muscle weakness may lead to further complications, such as respiratory failure, difficulty with mobilization, and increased risk of falls.
8. Infection: The patient's prolonged hospital stay and use of invasive devices may increase the risk of infection, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and bloodstream infection.
9. Organ dysfunction: The patient's prolonged hospital stay and use of invasive devices may lead to further complications, such as organ dysfunction, including liver, kidney, and cardiovascular dysfunction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's sepsis and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust anticoagulation therapy as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's DVT and adjust anticoagulation therapy as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dialysis therapy as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's pancreatic mass and adjust therapy as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's muscle weakness and adjust therapy as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's organ dysfunction and adjust therapy as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a complex medical history. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 103 beats per minute, blood pressure of 135/64 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute. The patient is receiving oxygen via nasal cannula and is on CPAP/PSV ventilator support.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.6 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 28.3%
* Platelet count: 270 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 9.0 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 23 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* Sodium: 154 mEq/L
* Potassium: 3.7 mEq/L
* Chloride: 28.3%
* Albumin: 2.5 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient has a diagnosis of:

* Acidosis, metabolic
* Deep venous thrombosis (DVT), upper extremity
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction
* Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* Hypernatremia (high sodium)
* Renal failure, chronic
* Atrial fibrillation (AFib)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Impaired skin integrity

The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and sedatives. The patient is also receiving nutrition via a nasogastric tube and is being monitored for glycemic control.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Sepsis progression to septic shock
* Respiratory failure worsening to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Renal failure worsening to acute kidney injury
* Hypernatremia causing neurological symptoms
* Atrial fibrillation causing cardiac arrhythmias
* Deep venous thrombosis causing pulmonary embolism
* Impaired skin integrity causing wound infection

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient tolerated PSV this
   morning with NIF +28.
   - attempt extubation today
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   - OOB into chair today (PT consult)
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.  Levophed off.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. On PO amio now with rate mostly in
   90s-110s.
   - No lasix at this time as pt auto-diuresing post-ATN
   - pt. was on metoprolol as an outpatient for rate control, can consider
   restarting as BP improves
   .
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis with course to end on [**4-22**].  Fever may represent
   worsening of this process vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation
   vs. other occult infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not
   have an elevated WBC count and has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may
   not be able to mount a robust inflammatory response due to older age
   and general chronically ill state. CT negative for any drainable
   abscesses. B-glucan floridly positive (>500) which is not surprising
   given pt
s prolonged abx courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN.
   Yeast in urine and sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative x 2
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 9
   today). Plan for 10 day total course
   - On day 4 of fluconazole which was started for positive B-glucan (D1 =
   [**4-27**]).  Plan for 7 day course?
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Absent today.  Previously was difficult to assess as
   pt
s sensorium was not completely clear, however it was worrisome given
   his history of medically managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling
   well (1-3 times a day), C.diff neg x 2, and has no residuals with TF.
   KUB neg for ileus or obstruction. LFTs, amylase, lipase all WNL.
   - Will hold off on further investigation for now; talk to patient once
   extubated for better history. The next step would be CT of abdomen and
   pelvis.
   - Continue TF as tolerating well with no residuals.
   .
   # Hypernatremia: better with D5W.
   - hold off on further D5W infusions; give PRN after checking PM lytes
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Resolving. Cr better this morning at
   1.3. UOP very good with likely post-ATN diuresis.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable after 2 u pRBCs on [**4-26**].   B12,  folate, & iron  within normal
   limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and
   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)
   off and on (with anticoagulation/INR 2.2)
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic 2.0 today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - increase warfarin again to 2.5 mg as INR barely therapeutic
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Vanc/zosyn and fluconazole as above
   - TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with free water flushes held pending
   extubation.  Will try on clears later today if successfully extubated
   and has a good gag.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; R fem
   CVC pulled [**4-28**].
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care, if does well post
   extubation, potential c/o to floor tomorrow.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

   well (1-3 times a day), C.diff neg x 2, and has no residuals with TF.
   KUB neg for ileus or obstruction. LFTs, amylase, lipase all WNL.
   - Will hold off on further investigation for now; talk to patient once
   extubated for better history. The next step would be CT of abdomen and
   pelvis.
   - Continue TF as tolerating well with no residuals.
   .
   # Hypernatremia: better with D5W.
   - hold off on further D5W infusions; give PRN after checking PM lytes
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Resolving. Cr better this morning at
   1.3. UOP very good with likely post-ATN diuresis.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable after 2 u pRBCs on [**4-26**].   B12,  folate, & iron  within normal
   limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and
   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)
   off and on (with anticoagulation/INR 2.2)
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic 2.0 today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - increase warfarin again to 2.5 mg as INR barely therapeutic
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Vanc/zosyn and fluconazole as above
   - TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with free water flushes held pending
   extubation.  Will try on clears later today if successfully extubated
   and has a good gag.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; R fem
   CVC pulled [**4-28**].
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care, if does well post
   extubation, potential c/o to floor tomorrow.

   worsening of this process vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation
   vs. other occult infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not

   chronically ill state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses.

   prolonged abx courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in
   urine and sputum. MRSA screen pos. CT abdomen showing no drainable
   fluid collection
   - C. diff negative x 2

   today- to be discontinued this afternoon)

   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)

   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .

   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - continue warfarin at 2.5 mg
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
